awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Disentangling CO2 Fluxes in a Tropical Rainforest Using Carbonyl Sulfide
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary objective of this CAREER project is to quantify gross carbon dioxide (CO2) fluxes in a tropical forest and obtain new understanding of processes linking these fluxes to environmental conditions. This project uses carbonyl sulfide (COS), an atmospheric trace gas, as a proxy for carbon dioxide uptake by plants, since both gases are consumed inside leaf cells by the same enzyme.  This method will be used to estimate Gross Primary Production (GPP) through photosynthesis in a tropical rain forest. The results will provide a better understanding of the carbon cycle and its role in the Earth system science. Both the Atmospheric Chemistry Program and the Ecosystem Science Program at NSF are supporting this interdisciplinary project. The Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program is a Foundation-wide activity that offers the National Science Foundation's most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations.

Three methods being employed for estimating ecosystem GPP in the rainforest are: (1) a field campaign to measure ecosystem fluxes of COS as novel tracer of GPP, (2) a network of distributed flux chambers to obtain new information on spatial and temporal patterns of plant and soil CO2 fluxes, and (3) an education-outreach program that will collect long-term data on CO2 fluxes across the forest canopy.  The field study will take place at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica, a site that has hosted over 12 years of ongoing rainforest research. The results of this research will help to answer questions such as how CO2 uptake responds to variations in soil moisture, light and temperature. The study will provide new information on the relationship of ecosystem respiration to changes in temperature during the day and night and help to explain how changes in GPP and ecosystem respiration contribute to large interannual fluctuations in both net ecosystem exchange and forest growth.

This research is well integrated with several educational activities, such as the development of a sensor lab course to provide advanced undergraduate students with hands-on field experiences.  There are also plans for an outreach program for K-12 students at the Stunt Ranch Reserve (a biological field station) in the Santa Monica Mountains and the creation of a Legacy dataset at the field site involving high school students and college level students from both the U.S. and Costa Rica.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical rainforests are currently important carbon sinks in the global carbon budget, but may change to a carbon source due to increasing temperature and water stress under ongoing climate change. Photosynthesis is the single largest uptake mechanism of atmospheric carbon dioxide, and the engine of the global carbon cycle. Earth system models predict that climate change will affect photosynthetic carbon uptake in tropical regions due to increased temperature and moisture stress. This could reduce the tropical land carbon sink and further amplify climate change. But projections of future tropical carbon fluxes have large uncertainties because photosynthesis cannot be measured directly at scales larger than a few leaves, and traditional flux partitioning methods do not work well in tropical rainforests. This means that we currently have very limited observational constraints on photosynthesis and respiration in tropical rainforests, which in turn limits our ability to diagnose and predict their responses to climate change in this globally important biome.

In this project, we applied a tracer, Carbonyl Sulfide (COS), that has its origins in atmospheric chemistry research and has recently been expanded to provide new insights into photosynthetic carbon uptake from leaf and ecosystem to regional and global scales. The project combined detailed field measurements in a tropical rainforest at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica, with mechanistic leaf and ecosystem modeling, and education activities at a local field site near UCLA campus. The outcomes of this project were: (1) New process understanding from high-resolution datasets of COS, CO2, and water fluxes at leaves, soil, and ecosystem scales collected in a tropical rainforest. We found that COS and COS:CO2 ratios in canopy air will be valuable tracers for vertical mixing and the distribution of leaf photosynthesis in tropical rainforests. We also identified a potential new application of above-canopy COS measurements for regional atmospheric chemistry studies. (2) We developed a new model-data fusion framework for the COS:CO2 leaf relative uptake (LRU) ratio based on the fundamental equations for photosynthesis and stomatal conductance. Our work enables COS to be added to global land biosphere models that do not have mechanistic COS gas exchange built in, which opens a path to COS-based model intercomparison. The study also provides a new way to use LRU ratios from laboratory or field datasets as a diagnostic tool of leaf-scale plant parameters that are currently poorly constrained, e.g. the slope of the Ball-Berry stomatal conductance relationship, one of the two key parameters in land biosphere models. (3) The project directly provided training for five early career scientists and eleven undergraduate students, with the majority (13) recruited from underrepresented groups in STEM. We developed a sensor lab course that is part of the regular in-person course offering at UCLA, where students have built portable flux chambers with low cost, open-source components as hands-on learning tools, and taken them on field trips to the Botanical Garden and our nearby field site, Stunt Ranch Reserve in the Santa Monica Mountains. We also developed two websites as teaching and education material to display real-time data from our two field sites at Stunt Ranch Reserve and La Selva, Costa Rica.

The intellectual merit of this project includes new insights into photosynthesis and gas transport within tropical rainforests, and new applications of COS as tracer in ecosystem and atmospheric chemistry research. The broader impacts include development of a lab sensor course and hands-on learning tools, development of education materials, and training of early career scientists and students from underrepresented groups.
